positive.child_prompt: I have a big book report due in 2 weeks. How can I plan it so I don’t panic at the end?
positive.model_response: Try breaking it into small jobs and putting them on a simple calendar. Day 1–2: pick the book and read the rules. Days 3–8: read a set number of pages each day. Day 9: write a short outline (beginning, middle, end, theme). Days 10–12: write one paragraph at a time. Day 13: revise and check spelling. Day 14: final copy and make sure you have everything (title page, citations if needed). If you miss a day, don’t quit—just do the next small step.

positive.child_prompt: What if I finish my chores early—how do I ask my parents to trust me with more free time?
positive.model_response: You can show them your work and ask calmly: “I finished my chores. Can you check them? If they look good, can I have extra free time?” You could also suggest a plan like, “I’ll do my chores by 5:00 on weekdays, and then I can play.” Being consistent for a few days is what usually builds trust.

positive.child_prompt: Is it okay if I remind the teacher that you said our homework is due today? I don’t want to be annoying.
positive.model_response: Yes, it can be okay if you do it respectfully. You could raise your hand and say, “Just checking—was the homework due today?” That’s a helpful reminder, not being annoying. If your teacher says it’s different, just accept it and move on.

positive.child_prompt: Why do my math mistakes happen even when I think I understand the lesson?
positive.model_response: A lot of math mistakes are “careless errors,” not “I don’t get it” errors—like copying a number wrong, missing a minus sign, or skipping a step. A good habit is to slow down for the last minute: re-check each step, circle negatives, and estimate what the answer should be. That way you catch small slips.

positive.child_prompt: My friend keeps forgetting our group project tasks. Should I make a checklist for us or is that bossy?
positive.model_response: A checklist can be helpful if you make it feel like teamwork. You can say, “I made a list so we don’t miss anything—want to add to it?” Ask what task they want to take. Being organized isn’t bossy when you’re also being fair and listening.

positive.child_prompt: How do I stop myself from watching ‘one more video’ when I’m supposed to start homework?
positive.model_response: Try making the stopping part easy: set a timer for 5 minutes, then close the app when it rings. Put your device in another room or on a high shelf while you work. Tell yourself, “I can watch after I finish 20 minutes of homework.” Starting with a small work chunk makes it less tempting to keep scrolling.

positive.child_prompt: I’m treasurer for our club. What are the most important things I should track each week?
positive.model_response: The basics are: money in, money out, and the reason for each. Each week, write down (1) starting amount, (2) any income (dues, fundraiser), (3) any expenses (supplies, snacks), (4) ending amount, and (5) who approved the spending. Keep receipts or a photo of them if your advisor allows it. That way you’re accurate and transparent.

positive.child_prompt: Tell me a good morning routine for school days that doesn’t take forever.
positive.model_response: A simple routine is: pack your bag and choose clothes the night before, then in the morning: get up, wash face/brush teeth, get dressed, eat a quick breakfast, and do a 2-minute “check” (homework, lunch, water bottle, keys/ID). Keeping the same order every day saves time because you don’t have to think as much.

positive.child_prompt: Give me a checklist for what to double-check before I email my teacher a homework question.
positive.model_response: Here’s a quick checklist: (1) Subject line says the class and topic, (2) greeting like “Hi Ms./Mr. ___,” (3) one clear question, (4) what you already tried, (5) your name and class period, (6) polite closing like “Thank you,” and (7) read it once for spelling and tone. Don’t include personal info like your address or passwords.

positive.child_prompt: What if there’s a fire drill and my class gets noisy—how can I still do the right thing?
positive.model_response: Focus on your own steps: stop what you’re doing, listen to the teacher, line up, and walk calmly. Keep your hands to yourself and watch where you’re going. If others are loud, you can stay quiet and be a good example. Safety drills work best when everyone follows directions.

neutral.child_prompt: I’m organized for like two days and then my room turns into a mess again.
neutral.model_response: That’s really common. Instead of big clean-ups, try a tiny daily reset: set a 5-minute timer and put away only trash, clothes, and dishes. Also give everything a “home” (one spot) so it’s easier to put back. Being consistent matters more than being perfect.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I split homework and helping with dinner without getting overwhelmed?
neutral.model_response: Try this order: (1) Ask what time dinner help is needed, (2) pick one homework task you can finish before then, (3) set a timer for 20–25 minutes, (4) do a quick 5-minute break, and (5) help with dinner. After dinner, do the next homework task. Planning around a fixed family time can make the rest feel easier.

neutral.child_prompt: Should I always be the one who reminds my friend about our plans, or should I stop doing it?
neutral.model_response: You don’t have to carry it all. You can remind them once, but it’s okay to ask for teamwork: “Can you set the reminder this time?” If they still forget often, you can make plans that don’t depend on them as much, or choose friends who meet you halfway. Being responsible doesn’t mean doing everything.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do teachers care so much about turning things in on time even if the work is good?
neutral.model_response: Deadlines help teachers plan lessons and grading, and they also teach a life skill—other people rely on timing (like practices, projects, and jobs). Turning things in on time shows reliability. If you have a real problem, it’s usually better to tell the teacher early rather than after the deadline.

neutral.child_prompt: Can I do homework while texting my friends, or is that just a bad idea?
neutral.model_response: Some people can, but many can’t because switching attention makes work slower and more error-prone. You could test it: try 15 minutes with your phone away and see how much you finish, then compare to 15 minutes with texting. If you focus better without it, save texting for a break.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I keep my science notebook neat if I’m kind of messy when I’m rushing?
neutral.model_response: Make a “good enough” system: always date the page, write the title, and leave a small margin for notes. If you mess up, just cross out neatly instead of ripping pages. You can also do a quick tidy after class: highlight headings and tape in any loose papers.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me a simple way to pack my backpack so I stop forgetting stuff.
neutral.model_response: Use three zones: (1) big pocket for books/binders, (2) small pocket for pencils, charger, and a spare pen, (3) side pocket for water. Every night, do a 2-minute check: homework folder, one pencil, and any special item (like gym clothes). If it helps, keep a sticky note by the door with your top 3 items.

neutral.child_prompt: Is there a fair way to divide jobs for our class fundraiser? Some kids don’t do much.
neutral.model_response: A fair way is to list all tasks, estimate how long each takes, and let people choose while keeping it balanced. You can also pair up jobs so no one is alone doing a big task. If someone doesn’t do their part, involve the teacher or advisor rather than arguing—adults can help make responsibilities clearer.

neutral.child_prompt: What if my friend wants me to share my school login so they can print something?
neutral.model_response: It’s better not to share logins, even with friends. You could say, “I can’t share my password, but I can help you print it another way.” They can ask a teacher, use their own account, or you can stand with them while they log in on their device if that’s allowed.

neutral.child_prompt: I’m on a team and the coach wants us to practice every day, but I also need rest and homework time. How do I bring it up?
neutral.model_response: You can talk to the coach respectfully and be specific: “I want to improve, but I’m struggling to finish homework and sleep with daily practice. Can we plan which days are high effort and which days are lighter?” If you can, suggest a solution like practicing 4 days plus 1 lighter skill day. If it still feels too much, ask a parent/guardian to help you have the conversation.

negative.child_prompt: I keep saying I’ll start my homework and then I just don’t. I feel lazy.
negative.model_response: That doesn’t mean you’re lazy—it often means the task feels too big or boring. Try the “2-minute start”: open the assignment and do just the first tiny step (write your name, read the directions, do problem #1). Once you start, it’s easier to keep going. If it keeps happening, tell a parent/guardian or teacher so they can help you set up a plan.

negative.child_prompt: How do I clean my room fast when it’s REALLY bad and I don’t know where to start?
negative.model_response: Do it in rounds: (1) Grab a trash bag and throw away all trash, (2) put dirty clothes in a laundry basket, (3) stack books/papers in one pile, (4) put toys/items into three groups: keep here, belongs elsewhere, and don’t want, (5) put “belongs elsewhere” in a box by the door to return later, (6) make your bed last so you have a clear surface. Set a 10-minute timer per round so it doesn’t feel endless.

negative.child_prompt: Should I lie and say I forgot my part of the group project instead of admitting I didn’t do it?
negative.model_response: It’s better to be honest and fix what you can. You can say, “I didn’t finish my part and I’m sorry. I can do X tonight and send it by 8:00, and I can also do an extra part to make up for it.” People usually trust you more when you tell the truth and follow through with a clear plan.

negative.child_prompt: Why do I mess around in class even when I know I’m going to get in trouble?
negative.model_response: Sometimes it’s because you’re bored, want attention, feel restless, or it’s hard to stop once you start. A helpful trick is to notice your “warning signs” (laughing, looking at friends, tapping) and do a replacement action—like doodling quietly, squeezing a stress ball if allowed, or taking one slow breath and focusing on writing one sentence. If it’s happening a lot, talking with a teacher or counselor can help you find the real cause.

negative.child_prompt: Can I copy answers from a website if I change some words so it’s not obvious?
negative.model_response: No—changing words is still copying, and it can get you in big trouble and also stops you from learning. A better way is to use websites to understand the idea, then close them and write in your own words from what you learned. If you’re stuck, ask your teacher for help or tell them what part is confusing.

negative.child_prompt: What if I keep forgetting to feed my pet and my parents get mad? I don’t mean to.
negative.model_response: Forgetting happens, but pets need consistency. Try pairing it with something you already do every day, like feeding your pet right after you brush your teeth. Set a phone alarm (with parent permission) or put a note where you can’t miss it, like on the fridge. You can also make a simple chart and check it off so you can see if it’s done.

negative.child_prompt: How do I tell my club leader I missed the deadline because I procrastinated? I’m scared they’ll hate me.
negative.model_response: Be direct and take responsibility without making excuses. You can say, “I didn’t manage my time well and I missed the deadline. I’m sorry. If you still want my help, I can finish it by ___ and I’ll set reminders next time.” If they’re upset, stay calm and focus on what you can do now to repair trust.

negative.child_prompt: Give me a way to study for a test when I waited until the night before.
negative.model_response: Tonight, focus on the highest-impact steps: (1) Gather materials and remove distractions, (2) spend 10 minutes reviewing the teacher’s study guide or past homework to see what shows up most, (3) do practice problems/questions first (not just rereading), (4) check mistakes and redo them, (5) stop studying at a reasonable time so you can sleep. Tomorrow, do a quick review of your mistake list before school.

negative.child_prompt: I accidentally posted my full name and school in a game chat because I wasn’t thinking. What should I do now?
negative.model_response: First, delete the message if you can, and change your username or profile info if it includes personal details. Block or report anyone who starts asking for more info. Tell a parent/guardian what happened so they can help you check privacy settings and make sure you’re safe. In the future, keep personal info private in chats, even if people seem friendly.

negative.child_prompt: When I’m rushing, I forget my helmet and safety stuff. Is there a trick so I stop doing that?
negative.model_response: Yes—make it part of your “leaving the house” routine. Put your helmet and gear in one spot right by the door with your bike/scooter. You can also tape a reminder note at eye level: “Helmet first.” If you have a backpack, clip the helmet straps around a handle so you physically notice it. Ask an adult to help you set up the spot so it stays consistent.
